options.description: Sure; let's pretend that that made sense
Can you speak clearly for once?
Oh; so you asked that in english? I must be crazy.
Cool; but my brain checked out after the first syllable; repeat.
Wow; that was a lot of effort for something I still don't get.
Cool; but my brain just blue-screened. try rebooting your point.
understand
Sorry I don't understand dumb. Do you have a dictionary for it?
That literally made zero sense to me.
Why do I even botter trying to understand you.
Why don’t skeletons fight each other? They don’t have the guts.
What do you call cheese that isn’t yours? Nacho cheese.
Why can’t your nose be 12 inches long? Because then it would be a foot!
Why did the bicycle fall over? It was two-tired.
What do you call fake spaghetti? An impasta.
Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field.
What’s orange and sounds like a parrot? A carrot.
Why couldn’t the pony sing a lullaby? She was a little hoarse.
How does a penguin build its house? Igloos it together.
Why did the golfer bring two pairs of pants? In case he got a hole in one.
What do you call a bear with no teeth? A gummy bear.
What’s brown and sticky? A stick.
Why can’t Elsa have a balloon? Because she’ll let it go.
Why don’t eggs tell jokes? They’d crack each other up.
What’s the best way to watch a fly fishing tournament? Live stream.
What did one wall say to the other? I’ll meet you at the corner.
What do you call a snowman with a six-pack? An abdominal snowman.
How does a scientist freshen their breath? With experi-mints.
Why did the math book look sad? It had too many problems.
Why did the tomato turn red? It saw the salad dressing!
Why don’t oysters share their pearls? Because they’re shellfish.
How does a train eat? It goes chew-chew!
What do you call a dinosaur with an extensive vocabulary? A thesaurus.
What did one plate say to the other plate? Tonight; dinner is on me.
What did the janitor say when he jumped out of the closet? Supplies!
Why did the computer go to the doctor? It had a virus.
What do elves learn in school? The elf-abet.
Why can’t you give Elsa a balloon? Because she’ll let it go.
What do you call an alligator in a vest? An investigator.
What did the grape do when it got stepped on? Nothing; it just let out a little wine.
Why don’t we ever tell secrets on a farm? Because the potatoes have eyes; and the corn has ears!
Why did the student eat his homework? Because the teacher said it was a piece of cake.
What did the ocean say to the shore? Nothing. It just waved.
Why do bees have sticky hair? Because they use honeycombs.
What kind of shoes do ninjas wear? Sneakers.
What’s a cat’s favorite color? Purrr-ple.
Why are ghosts bad liars? Because you can see right through them.
What musical instrument is found in the bathroom? A tuba toothpaste.
What do you call a cow with no legs? Ground beef.
What do you call a cow with two legs? Lean beef.
What’s Forrest Gump’s password? 1forest1.
What do you call a sleeping bull? A bulldozer.
What do you get when you cross a snowman and a dog? Frostbite.
Why was the belt arrested? It held up some pants.
Why did the picture go to jail? Because it was framed.
Why don’t skeletons go trick or treating? Because they have no-body to go with.
What kind of tree fits in your hand? A palm tree.
Why don’t bananas ever get lonely? Because they hang out in bunches.
What do you call an elephant that doesn’t matter? An irrelephant.
Why was the math book so stressed? It couldn’t figure out its angle.
Why did the cookie go to the doctor? Because it was feeling crumby.
What kind of music do mummies like? Wrap music.
What do you call a boomerang that doesn’t come back? A stick.
Why did the man put his money in the blender? He wanted to make some liquid assets.
What do you call a fish wearing a crown? A kingfish.
How do you organize a space party? You planet.
Why can’t a leopard hide? Because he’s always spotted.
What do you get when you cross a vampire and a snowman? Frostbite.
What’s the difference between a guitar and a fish? You can’t tuna fish.
What do you call two birds in love? Tweet-hearts.
How does the moon cut his hair? Eclipse it.
What do you call a dog magician? A labracadabrador.
Why did the broom get a promotion? It swept the competition.
What do you call a factory that makes okay products? A satisfactory.
How do you make a tissue dance? Put a little boogie in it.
Why are frogs so happy? They eat whatever bugs them.
What’s a pirate’s favorite letter? You think it’s R; but it really is the C.
What did the policeman say to his stomach? You’re under a vest.
Why don’t seagulls fly over the bay? Because then they’d be bagels.
Why did the coffee file a police report? It got mugged.
What do you call a duck that gets all A’s? A wise quacker.
How do you catch a squirrel? Climb a tree and act like a nut.
What kind of shoes do frogs wear? Open toad sandals.
What’s a snake’s favorite subject? Hiss-tory.
Why can’t your hand be 12 inches long? Because it’d be a foot.
Why don’t elephants use computers? They’re afraid of the mouse.
How does a barber cut the ocean’s hair? With sea-saws.
Why did the chicken join a band? Because it had the drumsticks.
What do you call a pig that does karate? A pork chop.
Why do seagulls fly over the sea? Because if they flew over the bay; they’d be bagels.
What do you call a sleepy kangaroo? A pouch potato.
What do you call a broken pencil? Pointless.
How do you make an octopus laugh? With ten-tickles.
Why did the kid bring a ladder to school? Because he wanted to go to high school.
Why are ghosts so bad at lying? Because they’re transparent.
What do you call a can opener that doesn’t work? A can’t opener.
Why was the sand wet? Because the seaweed.
How do cows stay up to date? They read the moos-paper.
What do you call a fish without eyes? Fsh.
Why are calendars always so popular? They have so many dates.
What do you call a singing computer? Adele.
Why did the mushroom go to the party? Because he was a fungi.
Why don’t crabs give to charity? Because they’re shellfish.
What do you call a belt made of watches? A waist of time.
Why did the banker switch careers? He lost interest.
Why can’t you trust stairs? Because they’re always up to something.
What do you call a story about a broken pencil? Pointless.
Why did the man get hit by a bike every day? He was stuck in a vicious cycle.
How do you make a lemon drop? Just let it fall.
Why do skeletons always stay so calm? Nothing gets under their skin.
What has to be broken before you can use it?
I’m tall when I’m young; and I’m short when I’m old. What am I?
What has a neck but no head?
What can you catch but not throw?
What gets wetter the more it dries?
The more you take; the more you leave behind. What am I?
What has hands but can’t clap?
What has a head; a tail; but no body?
What has many keys but can’t open a single lock?
What has one eye but can’t see?
hat comes down but never goes up?
What has cities; but no houses; forests; but no trees; rivers; but no water?
What can travel around the world while staying in the same spot?
What has an end but no beginning; a home but no body; and a bed but never sleeps?
The more of this you take; the more you leave behind. What is it?
Forward I am heavy; but backward I’m not. What am I?
What runs but never walks; has a bed but never sleeps; and has a mouth but never talks?
What begins with T; ends with T; and has T in it?
What has four wheels and flies?
What has lots of eyes but can’t see?
What has legs but doesn’t walk?
What comes once in a minute; twice in a moment; but never in a thousand years?
What goes up but never comes down?
What has teeth but cannot bite?
What is always in front of you but can’t be seen?
I’m light as a feather; yet the strongest man can’t hold me for long. What am I?
The more you take away; the bigger I get. What am I?
What has roots as nobody sees; is taller than trees; up; up it goes; and yet it never grows?
The person who makes it sells it. The person who buys it never uses it. The person who uses it never knows they’re using it. What is it?
What can fill a room but takes up no space?
What has a heart that doesn’t beat?
What has a face and two hands but no arms or legs?
What five-letter word becomes shorter when you add two letters to it?
What begins with an “e” and only contains one letter?
What is black when it’s clean and white when it’s dirty?
I have a head; a tail; but no body. What am I?
What can you hold in your left hand but not in your right?
I’m always on the dinner table; but you don’t get to eat me. What am I?
The more you take; the more you leave behind. What am I?
What can’t talk but will reply when spoken to?
The more of it you take; the more you leave behind. What is it?
I’m not alive; but I can grow. I don’t have lungs; but I need air. What am I?
The man who invented it doesn’t want it. The man who bought it doesn’t need it. The man who needs it doesn’t know it. What is it?
What runs but never walks; has a bed but never sleeps?
What is so fragile that saying its name breaks it?
What begins and has no end; and keeps turning but never stops?
What can go up a chimney down but can’t go down a chimney up?
I shave every day; but my beard stays the same. What am I?
What has one head; one foot; and four legs?
What comes at night without being called and is lost in the day without being stolen?
What has many needles but doesn’t sew?
I speak without a mouth and hear without ears. I have no body; but I come alive with the wind. What am I?
I’m found in the sky but also in the sea. What am I?
What can run but never walks?
What can you hold in your hand that can also hold water?
What belongs to you but is used more by others?
What has stripes and runs but never moves?
I’m often given but always kept. What am I?
I am full of holes; but I can still hold water. What am I?
I have keys but no locks. I have space but no room. You can enter; but you can’t go outside. What am I?
What starts with “P” and ends with “E” and has thousands of letters in it?
What comes once in a year; twice in a week; but never in a day?
I’m always running; but I never move from my spot. What am I?
I have no life; but I can die. What am I?
What has feet but no legs?
What can you throw but never catch?
What has words but never speaks?
I’m white; perfect for cutting and grinding. For most animals; I’m a useful tool. What am I?
What flies without wings?
What can be cracked; made; told; and played?
What has no beginning; end; or middle?
What kind of coat is best put on wet?
The more you take out of me; the bigger I get. What am I?
What can you break without touching it?
What starts off dry but gets wet as it works?
What has ears but doesn’t listen?
What is so light that even the strongest wind can carry it?
What has words; pages; and no voice?
What’s full of holes but still holds water?
What has an eye but never blinks?
What has a tongue but cannot talk?
What starts with “T” ends with “T” and is full of “T”?
I am not alive; but I can grow; I don’t have lungs; but I need air. What am I?
What is invisible but can be felt?
What can you keep after giving to someone?
What starts with “E” ends with “E;” but only has one letter in it?
What is something that is yours; but everyone uses?
I fly without wings; I cry without eyes. Wherever I go; darkness flies. What am I?
I’m light as a feather; yet the world’s strongest person can’t hold me for more than a few minutes. What am I?
What has no body; but a mind?
What has a ring but no finger?
What gets sharper the more you use it?
I disappear every time you say my name. What am I?
The more you feed me; the smaller I get. What am I?
What has four fingers and a thumb but isn’t alive?
What do you throw out when you want to use it but bring in when you don’t?
What is always moving but never arrives?
What is something you always overlook?
What can you hold without using your hands?
What grows the more you take away?
Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
A group of flamingos is called a "flamboyance."
Elephants can "hear" through their feet by detecting ground vibrations.
Cows have best friends and get stressed when they are separated.
The heart of a shrimp is located in its head.
Sloths can hold their breath for up to 40 minutes.
Starfish can regenerate lost arms and sometimes even grow a whole new body.
Giraffes only need 5 to 30 minutes of sleep per day.
Penguins propose to their mates with pebbles.
Some fish can recognize themselves in a mirror.
A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus.
Neutron stars are so dense that a sugar-cube-sized amount of their material would weigh as much as Mount Everest.
The Sun is about 4.6 billion years old and halfway through its lifespan.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on Earth.
Saturn could float in water because it’s mostly made of gas.
The Moon is slowly drifting away from Earth by about 1.5 inches per year.
Jupiter has 95 known moons (as of 2023).
Mars appears red because of iron oxide (rust) on its surface.
A single teaspoon of a black hole's material would weigh billions of tons.
The largest volcano in the solar system is on Mars. It’s called Olympus Mons.
Cleopatra lived closer in time to the moon landing than to the construction of the Great Pyramid.
The Eiffel Tower can grow up to 6 inches taller in summer due to heat expansion.
The shortest war in history lasted only 38 to 45 minutes (Anglo-Zanzibar War).
Napoleon Bonaparte was once attacked by a horde of bunnies.
The Great Fire of London in 1666 destroyed 80% of the city but only six people were recorded as dying.
Abraham Lincoln is in the Wrestling Hall of Fame for winning almost 300 matches.
Ancient Egyptians used honey as an antibiotic and a wound dressing.
Vikings used the bones of slain animals to strengthen their weapons.
Leonardo da Vinci was ambidextrous and could draw with one hand while writing with the other.
The ancient Romans used powdered mouse brains as toothpaste.
Bananas are berries; but strawberries are not.
Water can boil and freeze at the same time (called the triple point).
Lightning strikes Earth about 8 million times per day.
Humans share about 60% of their DNA with bananas.
Hot water can freeze faster than cold water under certain conditions (the Mpemba effect).
The human stomach gets a new lining every 3-4 days to prevent it from digesting itself.
Glass is actually a very slow-moving liquid; not a true solid.
The strongest material in the human body is tooth enamel.
If you stretched out all the DNA in your body; it would reach the sun and back about 600 times.
The average human body has enough fat to make seven bars of soap.
Canada has more lakes than the rest of the world combined.
Mount Everest is still growing by about 4 millimeters each year.
Antarctica is the largest desert in the world.
There’s a town in Norway called Hell; and it freezes over every winter.
The Amazon rainforest produces 20% of the world’s oxygen.
Russia spans 11 time zones.
Iceland doesn’t have any mosquitoes.
The Sahara Desert can reach temperatures of up to 58 degrees celcius.
The Dead Sea is so salty that people can easily float on its surface.
The Great Wall of China is not visible from space with the naked eye.
The first computer virus was created in 1986 and was called "Brain."
The first email was sent in 1971.
Apple’s first logo featured Sir Isaac Newton sitting under a tree.
The first 1 gigabyte hard drive; introduced in 1980; weighed over 500 pounds.
Bluetooth technology is named after a 10th-century Danish king; Harald "Bluetooth" Gormsson.
The "@" symbol was first used in email addresses in 1977.
The first website ever created is still online (info.cern.ch).
Amazon originally only sold books when it launched in 1995.
Nokia started as a paper mill company in 1865.
The world's first text message said "Merry Christmas."
Walt Disney was afraid of mice.
The voice of Mickey Mouse and the voice of Minnie Mouse were married in real life.
Barbie's full name is Barbara Millicent Roberts.
The first feature-length animated movie was "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs."
The "Happy Birthday" song is still under copyright in some places.
The first YouTube video was titled "Me at the zoo."
The Wizard of Oz’s ruby slippers were originally silver in the book.
Elvis Presley only won three Grammys in his entire career.
The longest-running TV show in history is "The Simpsons."
Superman first appeared in 1938 in Action Comics 1.
The Olympic Games were originally held in ancient Greece in 776 BC.
A baseball has exactly 108 stitches.
The first Super Bowl was held in 1967.
Golf is the only sport played on the Moon (by astronaut Alan Shepard).
The Stanley Cup is the oldest professional sports trophy in North America.
The fastest goal in soccer history was scored just 2.1 seconds after kickoff.
Basketball was invented by a Canadian called Dr. James Naismith.
Table tennis is the fastest ball sport in the world.
The first Wimbledon tournament was held in 1877.
The longest tennis match lasted 11 hours and 5 minutes over three days.
Your nose can remember 50000 different scents.
Humans have around 206 bones as adults but start with 270 as babies.
Your fingernails grow faster on your dominant hand.
Your skin replaces itself every 27 days.
The average human heart beats about 100000 times per day.
You produce about 25000 quarts of saliva in a lifetime—enough to fill two swimming pools.
The tongue is the only muscle in the body that is attached at just one end.
Humans are the only animals that blush.
The human brain generates enough electricity to power a lightbulb.
You can’t tickle yourself because your brain predicts the sensation.
The dot over the lowercase "i" and "j" is called a "tittle."
Wombat poop is cube-shaped.
The inventor of the Pringles can is buried in one.
The average cloud weighs about 1.1 million pounds.
A group of porcupines is called a "prickle."
Scotland’s national animal is the unicorn.
There’s a basketball court in the U.S. Supreme Court building.

Timmy let go of his red balloon and it soared high into the sky. He thought he'd lost it forever, but a friendly bird caught it and brought it back. Timmy hugged the bird and thanked it for being so kind.

An acorn dreamed of growing into a tall tree, but it was tiny and scared. One day, it decided to bury itself deep in the soil. Soon, a mighty oak tree sprouted, and the acorn realized bravery made dreams come true.

Every night, the stars twinkled in the sky, but one star dreamed of dancing. It leapt and twirled, making the whole sky sparkle with joy. From that night on, the stars always danced together, filling the night with magic.

Wally the worm wanted to see the world above the ground. He wriggled out of his hole and explored the garden, meeting bugs and flowers along the way. By the end of the day, Wally was proud of his new adventures and wiggled back home.
